title.narrative: Promoting the Empowerment of Angolan Women Through CSOs

description.narrative: The main goal of this project is to improve awareness and empower women to exercise their political, social and economic rights and theirby contribute ti the achivement of the MDG's and SDGs, through the provision of grants to CSOs

description.narrative: PIMS 4581 Angola National Biodiversity Project: Conservation of Iona National Park
IONA CONSERVATION/ GEF
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Park Manager and staff deployed, environmental assessment and infrastructures construction initiated, appropriate park equipment procured, functioning information sharing, conditions prepared for the elaboration of the Iona NP management plan, community profile report elaborated, human-Wildlife conflict issues identified 2. PLERNACA plan and engagement strategy implemented and adopted, human resources development programme for PAs implemented, evaluation implemented in 9 PAs, 6 PAs selected for further study, TORs created, project operation enabled 3. Staff employed, equipped and installed, project management enabled, communication plan implemented, database created and maintained

comment.narrative: 1. No existing staff, unsufficient infrastructure, lack of communcation and planning, basic level of Government support exists 2. "Strategic Plan for a National Network of Conservation Areas" (PLERNACA) approved, National Biodiversity Directorate (DNB) responsible for PAs at policy level and INBAC at implementation level, but for improved organizational, institutional and technical capacity is needed, limited information on the existing PAs, no management or implementation plan for any PA, Office space provided, M&E officer employed since Sep. 2012 3. Project to be initiated in 2013, Project Manager employed since Sept 2012, PAA selected, insufficient awareness and visibility to Angolan PAs at all levels

description.narrative: Objective: Catalyze an improvement in the overall management of the protected areas network, through rehabilitating Iona National Park
1. Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

comment.narrative: at least 10%

Progress made towards the target. 5% Government has invested USD6M in Iona Park infrastructure, rehabilitated the training school at Quicama National Park, the entry gate, herbarium and conference room.

description.narrative: 2. Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

comment.narrative:
Systemic: 42%
Institutional: 39%
Individual: 35%

Systemic: 55%
Institutional: 50%
Individual: 45%

Progress made towards the target. Systemic 46% - establishment of CBD for policy and strategic oversight over PAs Institutional 40% - INBAC fully functional and responsible for implementation of PAs management support programmes in addition a training school was rehabilitated in Kuando Kubango for development of rangers and Park Administrators. Park Administrators participated at the World Parks Congress to share and learn lessons for improved capacities. Individual 37%- 20 park rangers and 17 staff were trained on security and use of GIS, 2 Managers trained on GEF procedures.

description.narrative: 3. Total government budget allocation (including operational, HR and capital budget) (US$ per annum) for protected area management

comment.narrative: US$1.5 million (as at 2010/11)
At least US$8 million
Target achieved and surpassed by far. Government has allocated $82M for PAs in 2015 budget. Giving the target level of $8M the result is over 100%.

description.narrative: 4. Number of protected areas in which the METT is adopted as a tool to monitor effectiveness of PA management

comment.narrative: At least 7
The methodology of METT has been adopted for all 7 PAs. However only Iona Park has started using the tool for data collection. Other parks are expected to come on stream in the near future.

description.narrative: Outcome 1) Rehabilitation of Iona National Park

5. Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool scorecard:
Iona National Park

comment.narrative: 5 points out of 102 possible, giving (Jan 2012) = 5%. [NOTE ON LOGFRAME 2014:]We need to make a correction to the baseline. In the PRODOC, it mentions a 7% rate. However, 5 points was the final baseline score, and all questions were considered (none considered n/a). This gives a total possible points of 102 and a percentage of 5% at the baseline.

Target achieved, but this needs to be independently vetted. Considerable improvement in the METT score has been attained since the original evaluation of November 20, 2011. The June 2015 METT evaluation returned a score of 32/102 = 31% in comparison with only 5/102 = 5% in 2011. In the 2011 assessment only three questions (1, 5 & 6) were awarded positive scores totaling 5 of a possible 9 points. The same total score for these three questions was also awarded in 2015. However, of the 39 questions that received zero scores in 2011, 23 received positive scores in the recent evaluation indicating a wide-ranging improvement in management effectiveness. The target of at least 45% in the final evaluation is considered attainable.

description.narrative: 6. Number of park management staff appointed, equipped, trained and deployed in the park

comment.narrative: Approaching target. Same as last year.

description.narrative: 7. Percentage (%) of park visitors obtaining a permit to traverse/overnight in the park

comment.narrative: At least 80%

Progress made towards the target. 40% of Park visitors is reported. Registration and entry fees collection pilot system launch in October 2014, has been reformulated and submitted to the local government authority for approval.

description.narrative: 8. Proportion (%) of the plains grassland habitats of the park (~600km2) overgrazed by livestock (goats and cattle)

comment.narrative: More than 35% (by 2011/12)
Less than 20%

Not possible to assess the indicator with accuracy, but there are good indications that the baseline may have been optimistic and the target even more so. The aerial survey is yet to be conducted. Observations from the ground indicate an increase of at least 40% of the grassland habitats of the park overgrazed by livestock.

description.narrative: 9. Increase in wildlife populations: Oryx Hartmann's Zebra Springbok Ostrich

comment.narrative:
9b) Oryx: 1650
9b) Hartmann's zebra: 265
9c) Springbok: 2400
9d) Ostrich: 400

9a) At least 2000
9b) At least 300
9c) At least 3500
9d) At least 500

Progress made towards the general target. Road count reports increase in wildlife populations as follows:
9b) Oryx: 1815 = 10% increase, but still below target
9b) Hartmann's zebra: 270 = 1% increase, meaning no change, given data uncertainty, meaning basically status quo vis-a-vis baseline
9c) Springbok: 3120 = 30% increase and approaching the target
9d) Ostrich: 420 = 5% increase, but still below target

description.narrative: 10. Number of critical natural freshwater springs and wells secured and accessible for use by medium-sized and large wildlife species

comment.narrative: Not possible to inform indicator. The hydrological study and the park management plan are in progress.

description.narrative: 11. Number of poaching incidents (park visitors) recorded in the park/annum

comment.narrative: No data
Less than 12

Target achieve. Less than 12. Shots were heard in Mupaca area located at east of Iona and further east towards Helola and Montenegro areas. Motorcycles are used to hunt wild animals within the Park in the south of Espinheira.

description.narrative: 12. Proportion (%) of communities living in the park that are adequately represented in the park management decision-making processes.

comment.narrative: More than 60%

No change. 0% of communities living in the park are represented the park management decision-making processes. Community study and park management planning initiated but are not yet at the stage of informing the project on this indicator.

description.narrative: 13. Number of job opportunities (direct and indirect) created for local communities living in, or adjacent to, the park

comment.narrative:
a) Direct: 0
b) Indirect: 0

a) Direct: at least 10
b) Indirect: at least 30
Target partially achieved. a) Direct: 12 members of community are community agents (rangers) b) Indirect: 0

description.narrative: 14. Average annual income (US$) of households living in the park

comment.narrative: US$155/annum
At least US$250/annum
Not possible to inform indicator at this stage. The study on Community Profile is on going and data on income levels will be ready at finalization of the exercise.

description.narrative: Outcome 2) Strengthen institutional capacity to manage the protected areas network
15. Strategic Plan, and a policy framework, for the system of protected areas formally approved by government

comment.narrative: No
Yes
Yes.

description.narrative: 16. Organizational structure for protected areas and job descriptions, remuneration levels and conditions of service for protected area staff formally adopted by government

comment.narrative: No
Yes
Not possible to inform indicator at this stage. The Park Management Plan study is on going which will frame the organizational structure of the Park.

description.narrative: 17. Recruitment of staff to approved protected area posts in the organogram of the protected area agency (as a % of posts with permanent staff appointed)

comment.narrative: At least 50%
Target fully achieved. Current level remains as reported in 2014.

description.narrative: 18. Number of protected area staff completing in-service training and skills development programmes

comment.narrative: Target fully achieved. Further to the basic trainings conducted last year, 17 government staff of INBAC and Park Administrators of Mavinga, Luengue-Luiana, Chimalavera and Cangandala, were trained in GIS.

description.narrative: 19. Number of senior protected area staff in a structured mentoring programme

comment.narrative: Target partially achieved. 1 senior staff, the Iona Park Administrator continue to be mentored by the International Park Manager.

description.narrative: 20. Number of national parks and strict nature reserves with fully documented up-to-date assessments of their state and biodiversity value

comment.narrative: Initiated.

description.narrative: 21. Number of protected areas where a structured rationalisation and rehabilitation programme is adequately resourced and under implementation

comment.narrative: 1. Currently, only the Iona Park rehabilitation programme is under implementation. Target partially Achieved.

title.narrative: PPG 5166 Enhance Adaptive Capacity in Cuvelai Basin

description.narrative: Preparatory Phase (PIMS 5166): Promoting Climate -Resilient Development and Enhanced Adaptive Capacity to Withstand Disaster Risks in Angolan's Cuvelai River Basin

The initial plan is for development of a full sized Project (FSP) on *Promoting -Climate-Resilient Development And Enhanced Adaptive Capacity to Withstand Disaster Risks In Angolan's Cuvelai River Basin *.
independent political entity

comment.narrative: - Organize the LPAC meeting; - PRODOCs signature by the Ministry of Environment
The LPAC meeting was held. The implementation phase will start next year after the PRODOCs signature by the Ministry of Environment.

description.narrative: Sustainable Economy Development & Inclusive Gowth

title.narrative: Private Sector Development and Inclusive Growth

description.narrative: Sustainable Economy Development & Inclusive Gowth
policy, planning and administration

1. Number and scope of new South-South and triangular cooperation partnerships, PPP mechanisms that provide innovative solutions for inclusive growth 2. Number of schemes enabled to expand and diversify employment and livelihood opportunities for youth and women 3. Number of plans, strategies and analytical reports produced using high-quality, disaggregated data. 4. Number of policies and schemes that enhance access to social protection for the poor and other risk groups

comment.narrative: 1. 0 new South-South and triangular cooperation partnerships, PPP mechanisms provided innovative solutions for inclusive growth 2. 1 schemes enabled to expand and diversify employment and livelihood opportunities for youth and women (National Youth Development Plan). 3. 0 plans, strategies and analytical reports produced using high-quality, disaggregated data. 4.1 policies and schemes that enhance access to social protection for the poor and other risk groups (Angola National Development Plan 2013 - 2017)

- Capacities of MIREX and the inter-ministerial Committee implement and monitor the graduation Road-Map - MDPT impact study on potential impact of graduation on ODA completed. - Action plan designed and submitted to UN on graduation - Methodologies to identify and address needs for concentrated pockets of poverty developed and integrated in 3 strategies of selected Municipalities. - Facilitate the establishment of the country agribusiness supply chains and 3 sustainable value chain initiatives - Facilitate the conclusion of the National Strategy and action plan on domestic tourism - INAPEM strengthened for effective SMME development - National CSR Network established and functioning - Studies on strategies on increasing inclusive business practices and economic diversification promoted - Institutional framework for market oriented vocational education promoted. - Youth entrepreneurship competitions promoted. - At least one value chain benefiting women and youth developed. - MPTD supported to report on NDP and MDGs - Social Assistance Policy endorsed by National Assembly - MINARS strengthened for advocacy and implementation of new social policy

Angola has to draft a Smooth Transition Strategy and Road Map and for that they count with the UN Support. The GoA expects to draft the Strategy along 2016. UNDP is supported MINGEO with a consultancy on alignment of Angolan legislation and polices to the AMV. The studies on comparative value chain and Fiscal Regime of gold sector was concluded The National MDG Report conclude and thhe GoA, through MINPLAN is expecting before the end of the year to have a workshop with the UN support for the launching of the Angola MDGR 2015. At the same event the GoA with UN support wants to highlight the GoA with the SDGs, including a brief presentation of the SDGs in the same workshop. The Noin-Oil Value Chain analysis was concluded The National Corporate Social Responsibility established.

description.narrative: Participation and Local Governance

1. Decentralization policies/laws revised 2. Participation in processes of governance improved 3. Local administration capacity strengthened

comment.narrative: 1. Law 17/2010 on decentralization 2. Existence of institutions and national programs for training of civil servants at central, provincial and local levels

1. National framework and strategies for effective decentralized governance strengthened 2. Local level development dialogue forums supported - 1 pilot 2. 2 CACs capacitated for enhanced and effective participation in local decision making 2. Partnership framework developed to support women and youth CSO networks for development dialogue 3. MAT institutional capacities strengthened to support the implementation of national decentralization policy 3. IFAL institutional capacity strengthened for delivery of local administration training

1. National debates on decentralization experience launched towards the development of national strategy and framework for local elections [2015] 2. Partnership formed with Government to foster active youth and women citizen platforms [2015] 2. 2 CACS capacitated for enhanced and effective participation in local decision making [not achieved] 2. Local level development dialogue forums supported - 1 pilot [ongoing] 3. 151 IFAL staff trained [2015] 3. MAT institutional capacity strengthened [not achieved]

comment.narrative: - Design and development of the PRODOC

Meetings were held with civil society, university and government throughout the year in order to collect baseline information and experiences on the sector. These meetings were key for design and development of the PRODOC, which is being finalized.

description.narrative: Empowering Women Project - MINFAMU

The aim of this partnership is to support the National Gender Office to strengthen its institutional capacity at both central and decentralized provincial levels, as well as the capacity building of CSOs and Women Community Based Organizations.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)
1. Capacity building activities for MINFAMU 2. Number of CSOs and Women Community Based Organizations engaged

comment.narrative: 1. MINFAMU sectorial plan, part of the National Development Plan - NDP (2013-2017) 2. National Policy on Gender Equality and Equity (PNIEG 2014 -2017) approved in 2013 3. Lack of data and weak institutional capacity

1. MINFAMU's capacity to promote and to monitor implementation of PNIEG and its Action Plan strengthened 1. MINFAMU's capacity to advocate and coordinate gender mainstreaming in development enhanced 1. National capacities for collection, analysis and utilization of gender disaggregated data reinforced

1. 145 women trained in skills and on legal framework for community organizing [2014-2015] 1. Gender equity and equality policy brochures published [2015] 1. MINFAMU staff participated in international forums on gender [2015] 1. Ongoing mapping of CSOs that work on gender [2015]
